content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												This game is honestly very good.  You're easily getting a game worth more than the $5 you're paying for it.  What I like about this game is being able to individually control all of your people, giving them jobs, equipping them, etc..  Your man power actually matters in this game instead of them feeling like dead weight like they did in State of Decay.  In SoD you pretty much had to do everything yourself as the player.  In this game, you actually have to delegate orders to ALL of your community members unless you want to run back and forth hauling boards and chicken wire a few at a time.  Your community actually feels like, a, well, community.  It's not unlike in SoD where you radio in for someone to come grab stuff while being arbitrarily limited by the game.  It's the same principle, but a very different execution.  Whereas SoD focuses more on exploration and beating up zombies, Survivalist focuses more on the town building.You get this game for the awesome town and community building aspect.  If you want to run around slaughtering zombies, there are better alternatives, like State of Decay, because that is not the object of this game.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												This isn't so much a review as a letter of appreciation for the developer. I feel guilty I only paid $5 dollars for this game. If you decide to crowd-fund your next game, please make note of it on your blog so people can donate.  I have gotten an immense amount of fun out of Survivalist, far beyond its actual retail price. I've tried to figure out why this game was so addictive for me, and I think it comes down to a combination of the post-apocalyptic setting, the crafting and community building element, the exploration system, and the strategy and foresight required to reach the end of the game. If these elements appeal to you individually, the combination of them will bring you many days of fun.There were bad times though. The first few hours, I derisively referred to this game as Insulin Quest.  Watching my team split up and run off in four different directions because I was walking to close to a the edge of a cliff was a serious, recurring frustration. I became more afraid of slight elevations than I was of White Strain infected. I also did not like that human-on-human violence played such a big, hard-wired role in the game.But nonetheless I couldn't put the game down until I had beaten it and replayed it, and I can't recommend it enough to anyone who appreciates those good qualities I have described.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												This game is GREAT! I have no idea why Steam keep pushing Early Access scams on my front page, when there are brilliant games like this already available. I had never heard of it. I also always wanted to play a Action-RPG/RTS Hybrid with Base Building... this scratched the itch with its zombified claws.--INTRODUCING you to Survivalist. One of the few Indie titles that really lives up to its screenshots and descriptions, this can easily get you hooked for hours.Play as you like: be the careless, selfish, evil badass people like to think you are, be the paragon savior of the land, or decide for yourself who deserves to keep breathing in a world where trust is the best currency.Do you seek Money, Power or Love?GRAPHICS and AUDIO are good and more than enough for what the game was trying to accomplish.CONTROLS are simple: WASD to move, right-click to aim and swipe mouse horizontally or vertically to change target or change aim (legs/body/head), left-click to fire/use/select, mouse-wheel to select dialogue options.Pressing Control will enable Command Mode, in which you can give orders or assign job (or roles) to your characters.You can also press F to pause, or G to Fast-Forward up to 4x speed.From F1 to F4 you can select the menus (Inventory/Community/Quests/Map screens). Therefore, no need for crazy hand-dancing when equipping your 5 new recruits!COMBAT is also simple and straightforward. Almost all ZOMBIES are fast-moving, and there are different zombies strains, which means each strain is stronger than the other. You'd be smart to adapt yourself and your squad when fighting weaker enemies to preserve ammo, or stronger enemies to prevent instant deaths if bitten. Also, remember to bring some antigen ("antidote") and bandages!Against LOOTERS (or human opponents in general), not being able to command your people tactically can make combat against well-armed looters rather hard and chaotic if you're not geared up properly - so get your squad some bulletproof vests before attempting some post-apocalyptic genocide! Still, with a little thinking, you can get through anything, and it feels great when you clear an enemy base with no one hurt.ROLE PLAYING: Your actions will change the opinions of those around you (or your whole community views of you, or the whole city you're in, or the whole region). This can make it easier or harder for you to recruit and convince people. You can also give gifts to the characters to make them like you, or perform shakedowns to keep them in check and to show who's boss.BASE BUILDING: Give a man a hammer, and he'll build you Walls and Concrete Watchtowers for a lifetime.Defend your base perimiter with Wooden and Wire walls and gates, build wooden or concrete watchtowers and pillboxes to make your enemies think three times before trying to molotov your base to the ground!You'll also need to provide housing, outhouses, food and water to your people.MICROMANAGING your community member's gear is necessary, but should only take a minute for every member you recruit for the different roles. Some roles the members can take, like Farming and Guarding, doesn't need micromanagement. Farmers will water the plants, harvest, and plant as necessary. Guards will enter any available towers - your guards will keep cycling locations at every "shift", which looks really cool and natural.The Collector (Bring Materials to Base) and Builder roles will need to have orders assigned. For the Collector, you tell which building he should go to, and which item he should bring from there.NOTE: I don't know if characters pick up ammo from the base on their own, but the only time someone had low ammo was a guy collecting wood on his own and walked through a pack of 6 zombies - which I should have made him avoid.As far as BUGS go, being halfway through the game and halfway through the map, I haven't found any. CONCLUSION: Definitely try the demo. And if you like it, then buy it, and spam the forums begging for a sequel.PERSONAL NOTE: This is one of the very rare occasions, within our current market, in which a game not only delivers what it promises, but costs (criminally) less than it should. It's less promoted than more expensive "indie" (kickstarted) games who were abandoned by the developers (yet are still available on Steam and being put on sale). I have bought 60USD Triple-A incomplete and bug-ridden titles, and this game made (apparently) by a single guy on his spare time gave me way more fun than a lot of games I've purchased these last few years.With more complexity and depth, a sequel could take the market by storm.Thanks for reading, I hope I helped in some way!--BONUS PROTIP: Change your Quick Save key to F5 [or other key]. I was forced to murder a whole innocent town because I acidentally pressed Quick Save twice and it overwrote Auto Save slots. Save often to avoid making dumb mistakes like me :)

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												The game offers pretty much all it advertised, something I thought rather rare for a 5 € game.You're pretty much thrown into the post-apocalyptic world unawares, unequipped, climbing out of your Vault (where have I seen this before?) and completely unprepared for the horrors outside. Thankfully, the game's first tutorial run provides an easy crash course into the game world and mechanics, first strolling you thru combat, party interactions, building bases and trading and so forth.You'll soon be on your way to building your own post-apo settlement to your own whims, within certain limitations. In addition to your zombie neighbours (colour-coded for your convenience), you'll be setting up diplomatic relations with other settlements in the neighbourhood, with various shantytown or lone survivors out in the boons.What I did like about the game world was the surprising outcomes and twists in quests- instead of plain boring fetch quests, you can sometimes blunder right into a moral dilemma that needs to be solved on the spot, usually either resulting in placating hostiles, or turning previously friendly forces into hostiles, or score some extra loot or survivors for your settlement.So, I was somewhat pleasantly surprised when I was tasked with 'wiping out Looters' (the staple of the post-apocalyptic quest world), and instead of brutally gunning everybody down, I was given the choice of sparing a survivor of the group, recruiting them for my cause, instead of persisting in the silly tradition of game foes have of fighting to the death, even against unwinnable odds.Another time, I was sent to kill looters who stole food from a settlement- only to find out the truth to the matter was not all black and white, as the quest giver had originally let on.Overall, the game is no State of Decay, Dead State, Rebuild: Gangs of Deadsville or Project Zomboid, but it has it's moments- the combat mechanics tend to be very twitchy, with split seconds to open fire on the Infected, as they barrel down on you from the desert with a hankering for survivor flesh. The infection mechanic is pretty simple- you get bit, you gotta get an antidote. Different strains of the disease have different germination times, with the worse strains taking down the host in minutes, requiring survivors to have the proper antidote at hand, or succumb to the disease themselves. Ammo is usually pretty abundant, and you even score 10.000 pistol rounds in the first hour of the game, so you are unlikely to run out of ammo for the basic shooter during your first days. By day 5, I had enough ammo to spare, equipping most of my resource mules with shotguns, my main character with a automatic rifle and farmers and builders with pistols.Instead of bottlecaps, food and water, your main currency in the wasteland is gold, which is surprisingly abundant in spite of the whole apocalyptic scenario. I found this somewhat funny that while the game makes it clear that paper money is worthless, the concept that the new economy would be based on a non-essential luxury item is kind of a strange notion. Still, it's no a big deal- you'll end up doing more barter than plain gold trading most of the time, anyway.So, to summarize:PROS:+ Freebuild of your own settlement, within some limitations+ Additional diplomacy and unexpected realism with some sidequests, moral dilemmas+ Game's difficult, but does not punish you horribly+ You can delegate resource fetching, farming, building+ Survivor AI is not completely helpless if left to their own devices. Pathfinding is decent.CONS:- The minimap and survivor topdown view are much too close, even on 1920x1080 resolution, giving the game a 640-x480 look.- Sometimes survivor messages on the right zoom past at astounding speeds, and you miss whatever tooltip or notice was in question.- Your survivors are practically blind, barely able to see ten feet in any given direction, so they'll constantly get bushwhacked by super-fast, feral zombies until the route is cleared with buckshot, which brings me to...- Fast undead. Combat is arcade-y, twitchy, sometimes almost Press 'X' not to die.- Survivor animations on walk and run are a bit wonky.- Molotov aiming is a game of chance.- Some of the music tracks are really tiring. Others, not so bad.Still, for five bucks, this game is not a bad investment, and probably a good diversion to anyone else who enjoys zombies and town management mixes.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												The game has all the content to be a great survival game - scavenging, base constructing, farming, item crafting, diplomacy, trading... unfortunately it suffers from a terrible lack of balance that completely breaks realism.First, the zombies aren't actually 'fast zombies', they are 'olympic runner zombies'. They will charge you from beyond your seeing distance at the speed of a cheetah and then lunge at you from 3 meters away to tackle you. Combat is just 'dodge - shoot - dodge - shoot' until your enemies are dead. There's no room for strategy/tactics or even a little bit of thinking. It isn't difficult, but it lacks depth and quickly becomes uninteresting. And in case you're wondering, there's no stealth mechanic so zombies always aggro you before you can see them, no way around this.The shooting mechanics are also frustrating - guns are very inaccurate even at close range. The characters could miss the side of a barn at 10 feet, literally. And since zombies have quite a bit of health, you'll empty a few clips to kill them. If you wait without moving long enough, you can make a perfectly accurate shot but this rarely happens since you're fighting marathon runner zombies. The time it takes to aim a perfect shot at 3 feet is way too long anyway to be realistic.Then there's ammo - there's too much of it lying around to be realistic or to feel like you're struggling to scavenge for supplies. Out of bullets? Just search the nearest house or car and I guarantee you'll find enough to kill a few zombies. Yes, since guns are so inaccurate it's a good thing there's lots of ammo, but why not just make guns more accurate and give the player less ammo? At least it would feel realistic and like you're actually in a post-apocalyptic world were supplies are scarce. Right now it feels like the entire US Air Force airdropped all their ammo reserves over the game map.Next problem is the inventory size. Characters can't carry a lot of stuff without backpacks so scavenging runs are very unproductive. The ammo you need to carry with you also takes up a lot of inventory room even if you just carry enough at once to kill 5 zombies. This isn't a problem when you have backpacks, but it can take time to find them. And by the way, you NEED a backpack if you want a character to do any construction. Construction requires you to carry a heavy toolbox + construction materials, you can't just drop the materials at the construction site and then come back with the tools to complete the job. Without a backpack, most characters don't have enough inventory room to build anything. That means when you leave someone at base to build stuff, that's one less backpack you can give your guys going out to find supplies. It also means the first backpack you find won't help you scavenge because building barricades will be more important at that point, so you'll have to keep looking for another one if you want your scavenging runs to actually become productive.Then there's the time lapse. The days just go by too fast. Your characters have to regularly eat, drink, sleep and some have medical conditions that require taking meds like diabetes/insulin. So whenever I speak to an NPC, I feel like I'm wasting precious time. Seriously, a 2 minute conversation feels like a terrible, unproductive waste of time. I never ask NPCs about their backstory, I only use dialogue for quests or trading. And when I speak to an NPC, I just quickly fly over the dialogue.And with time flying by so fast, well you need to get food and meds quickly. Your characters will eat them up almost faster than you can get them, especially the meds. Just like with combat, there's no time to think or plan, you have to keep moving.This isn't a survival game, it's a fast-paced arcade game with survival elements. And it's a shame, because it could be an awesome survival game just by modifying a few variables.Sure, it's only five bucks. But then again, it's a game I quickly gave up playing with no intention of playing it again. It's a game I want to enjoy, but it needs modifications to be an actual survival game and less of an arcade game. Right now it feels like the devs just had no idea how to balance difficulty properly in a game, so they made zombies sprint, they made your guns less accurate than a nerf gun, and then they gave you thousands of ammo lying around everywhere to make sure you wouldn't run out.Would sure be nice if they fixed this or at least provided a minimum of mod support. It's just stupid how close this came to being a really great game in it's genre, yet failed completely.

Posted: March 6, 2015
												Easily one of my favorite games on Steam and totally worth the 5€ (if not way more). Looks cheap and stupid, but gives you tons of playtime and finally a great mix of story, survival, sandbox and RPG. All in all it's kept simple, which is more than ok considering the price and being an Indie, but that doesn't make the fun smaller. If I would compare it to another game, than State of Decay (which I love,too). Survivalist is simpler, top down, weak graphics, less items, less challenging and a smaller world, but gives you a story with choices to make and more "open world" feeling, survival gets more important and finally you not just can control everyone, but also form groups and give your community members jobs to do (farming, guarding, supply runs, building...or just control several groups via strategy mode or by switching through the groups). And ofc there is building. Not just "This is ma base, I build a kitchen here", but building up a base you like. You start with a single bunker and then you can add shacks, barns, wells, farming ground, walls and several defense buildings whereever you want.From time to time zombies or looters attack your base, so you have to organize a defense. But not all looters need to be killed. Some group of looters you can find will threaten you, but there are some ways to avoid fighting and even recruit them. Socializing is an important part in the game, although generally kept simple. The creativity to solve quests sometimes reminded me of fallout (for example !SPOILER! there will be a quest killing a gay couple. You can either just kill em, talk with them, kill the person that gave you the job, just lay down the quest and lose the chance to get some extra insulin...or not? You can actually lay down the quest and then rob the quest giver for the key to the insulin, and if you do it right, you won't even get the revenge for robbing here)So yeah..blablabla yada yada yadaBuy game, game great.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
Survivalist ReviewWhen I was first asked to do a review for Survivalist, I admit that my expectations were a bit low due to the old-school graphics and the relatively low price on an indie game developed and published by a single individual I hadn't heard of before. Being a veteran of survival, RPG, and all types of strategy games in general I still intended to give a fair review based on the game's content. Twenty minutes into the game all i could say was "Wow!" This game is amazing and so much fun. It masterfully mixes Survival, RPG, RTS, and Action elements into a highly addictive adventure that will entertain you for numerous hours and even at full price I strongly recommend this game to fans of all these genres. Not convinced? Then read on...In Survivalist the ultimate goal is obviously to survive yet another zombie apocalypse. Except that these zombies offer a greater challenge than typical survival games. The infection has multiple strains with varying effects and incubational periods before turning into a zombie yourself. Each will require an antigen specific for that particular type. Another difference is that these zombies are incredibly fast and agile. Don't expect to outrun them. In this game its fight or die. Surviving will ultimately depend on building a strong community of people working together. You will need to build a strong base able to defend against attacks. It will also need to provide other basic basic needs to survivors like clean drinking water, fresh crops of food, shelter and hygiene. This will require you to recruit people with varying skills, gather an assortment of building materials, and collect items that can be useful. There are many NPC's in the game and most of them can be pursuaded in different ways to join your community. Players can use gifts, perform tasks, or even strong-arm characters into joining. There are countless possibilites based on dialogue and other decisions made over the course of the game. Its really nice how all choices have consequences. And, don't be fooled. Not everybody you encounter is a friendly face ready to welcome you with open arms. There are other survivor communities and bands of looters scattered across the map with their own needs in mind.Members of your community can be assigned to perform different jobs either by direct control or by using the command feature which will enable you to avoid the hassles of micromanagement. Individuals have a handful of stats that level up through use of that particular skill. They are affected by respect and approval ratings even after being recruited so they can decide to leave your community if they become unhappy with your leadership skills. These are just some of the many challenges that this game offers.The Good:=======+  Solid story and quality content+  Numerous options and variety of choices+  Entirely sandbox and open (aside from the tutorial)+  UI is easy to use+  Good quality graphics+  Sound quality+  Rotating camera+  Full controller support+  High replay value+  Realistic concepts+  Variable speed settings+  Stability (lack of bugs and crashes)+  Low requirements/runs well on older machines+  Steam Achievements+  Developer friendly and active in communityThe Bad:======-  No option to turn tutorial hints off-  No ambient sounds in background-  No useful vehicles or items for transporting resources-  Crafting is minimal (somewhat abandoned concept?)-  Could be multiplayer or co-op?Final Thoughts:===========Survivalist is definitely one of those games Steam users won't want to miss. I strongly recommend picking this game up if you're a fan of Survival, RPG, RTS, or Action  games and the price is unbeatable for the content you receive. Forget about the fact that its made by one person on a low budget rather than by an entire development team with studio backing. This game can easily compare to big name titles like State of Decay and hold its own. Yes, the game is that good.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

Posted: August 17, 2015
												This game costs only £4, but it contains hours of fun for those who want to enjoy a zombie apocolypse game where you build your own community.I adore this game. The choices you make can define how your gameplay is, such as: Should I recruit this group of five to my community? They could be used for guarding, farming or constructing buildings, but they also need to be fed which can drain my supplies and risk my other survivors' lives if they venture out to get more food for them.I am very impressed by this game, considering that it costs such a small price is a big surprise for the quality of it. I wish we could see more games like these more and State of Decay. I adore a game where you build a community during an apocolypse or other circumstances. The only cons I would say about this game is that the camera angle and this 'fog of war' that limits your visibility to such a small sight, by the time you've seen a group of infected and raised your gun, they're already on top of you and infecting you. I have had this happen quite often, which is an annoyance. The other con would be the unecessarily fast zombies in this game, there is nothing that has annoyed me more than having one of my runners ambushed by a group of infected and then constantly caught by them when they try to outrun them, eventually they either get caught and bitten due to the poor fatigue that takes a long time to improve or they waste all their ammo on shooting them whilst moving, which is irritating due to the poor accuracy when moving even when a survivor is right in front of them.Overall, there are improvements to be made, but this game at the current moment is great in my opinion.

												I recommend this game. It was $5!  It's honestly worth $30 easy. Survivalist:This is one of the best zombie games I have played in years...  I know there are others LIKE it, but not with this much in it. I have been looking for a new zombie game and lucky for me, there was a demo. I got the demo, played it, then payed for the game instantly.  The demo was good but the game has so much more to offer.Little did I know there was this much packed into in this one game. PROS:- low price - high entertainment value- i don't need a rockin 8 gb (of RAM), a $400.00 video card, and or 15 gigs of harddrive(ROM) space to play- the download/install is short and quick- no tick, no glitch, no crashing... at all... ever... - a sandbox frame- the camera view and controls are good (360 view)- zombies (vary from slow/easy to "Lost my brains!")- zombie attacks are scary and get my blood pumping- the chance to contract a virus and not end the game - plenty of guns and of ammo- the ability to build a base (however I want to build it)- the ability to build a dynamic community of people, of whom I chose- the ability to make my community self-sufficiant(sp?)- a realistic level system to advance each member of my community - plenty of quests that all have a start, finish, and reward, etc...- the ability to SAVE my game (thank you sooo much for that)- replay factor is greatCONS:- graphics are a bit lacking, however after playing for a few min this is not a problem, AND it I think it keeps the gameplay smooth for all kinds of computers- the soundtrack is absent and this can make or break any game, however I think the quietness and just ambient noises set the realism up to a higher level, in a good way... listening for brain-snackersOn a scale of 1 to 10, 1 = bad, waste of time and money10 = great, best entertainment money ever spentI give it a 9. Fantastic job! Hope to see more from them in the future! I WILL buy the next game they release if any in the future.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												TL;DR: A surprisingly deep, yet inexpensive, game that covers a lot of ground left undisturbed by many titles in the survival genre. I highly recommend it!Survivalist has a lot of things going against it, to be honest. It's one of a plethora of titles in the survival genre, it employs a very basic graphics package, and it's developed by a relatively small shop, just to name a few. That said, in my opinion it far surpasses so many of its peers in so many ways. Here's my short list of exactly how it does it:- Choices matter. Virtually everything you do has consequences, including your interactions with the environment, your community (i.e. the survivors who join you) and NPCs. These consequences do have some remedies, but they take work to get around.- There's a lot of quests/missions. In my playthrough, almost nothing has to be done in a particular sequence, in that you can put things on hold if you like and do your own sandbox thing for a while.- Strategy AND tactics. You can choose the RTS controls for some overarching activity, and then take control of a particular character to make sure something is done the way you want it. Perfect for your micromanaging streak while allowing you accomplish a lot of the mundane stuff without pulling your hair out.- Scavenging. The map is full of useful stuff, and you get to choose how to use it, particularly when it comes to building your base.- Replay value. This relates strongly to the first point dealing with choices, but because almost everything can pivot the game in at least a small way, things can be very different depending on what you choose.- Performance. My machine is definitely middle-of-the-pack, but it has no issue running this game with several different background apps.- Active development. The developers just released a major patch today that implements online co-op, and they've been regular about updates and bug fixes since launch.There are some things to be aware of that some people won't find that attractive. - The graphics are very basic, but it's by design. - The crafting system is rudimentary, but you also don't have to pull your hair out putting things together. - Music gets a bit repetitive.Seriously, for the money, it's going to be very difficult to get a game that rivals all you can enjoy here. Really well done!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Survivalist is the single greatest zombie survival game there is at the time of writing; and it is also the game that has SURPRISED me the most in my entire life. On the outside, or during the first 15 minutes of the game, you'll be taken aback by the hilariously ill-fitting music, the goofy character models, and the almost robotic animations. But anyone who has played the game for more than an hour or two will tell you that the game is so much more than that.There are a lot of things that this game excels at, and things that it does as good as (or better than) any other game in the genre.1. COMPLETE CONTROL: Nobody is invincible, and you can choose the fate of absolutely anyone in the game.2. OPEN WORLD: The open world is massive and is full of people and places to trade and loot.3. COMMUNITY: The game handles building your community extremely well, and you can manage everything that goes on behind your gates, such as assigning roles in the community.4. WELL WRITTEN: The story is full of twists and turns, some deliberately predictable, others that will actually make your jaw drop. (Those who've played the love ending know what I'm talking about...)5. COMBAT: While extremely simple, combat in this game is excellent and always feels brutal. Every hit counts, enemies die quickly and so do you. Bring a bulletproof vest...6. IT'S TERRIFYING: Running out of supplies is a death sentence, and being bitten and not having any cure is a stressful experience, and early on without good equipment, A LOT of people will die unless precautions are taken. Venturing into unknown territory is a massive risk/reward as well. It's scarier than most horror games out there!7. IT IS SO MUCH FUN!: I know this one's cheating a bit, but honestly, risk can pay off, and when it does, it's a glorious feeling, and I know that anyone who can be bothered to play the game for more than an hour will realise that this game is both deep and detailed.Also, if you've enjoyed the game, please take the time to go on the discussions page and thank Bob, the maker of this game. He has put in so much effort into making this game amazing, and he deserves all the praise he gets.In all honesty, I would pay £30 for this game. There is so much in the game to do for such a low price. Enjoy the game, it's absolutely marvellous!GOTY 2015

												Actually a surprisingly entertaining game, chose to go ahead and purchase this on steam since i had a few extra bucks and it sounded interesting but i didnt expect much and at first it didnt seem like much, bleak boring desert (for the love of god devs, gtfo of the desert) But when you get into the game it becomes an interesting management game where you loot and clear towns, fighting off looters and zombie waves, So i decided i liked the game and worked on it for a bit, got to a certain point and realized the error of my ways so i did a new game. I read someone saying its a linear game, with little open world aspects, well they are wrong to put it nicely, instead of helping alice you can just walk up and blow her head off and go kill everyone else you see if thats what tickles your pickle, but personally i liked finding a few good guys, getting their skills up then hunting down raiders and forcing them into my group.End of the day its a great game that seems very underrated, you can buy it on the xbox360 aswell, which i did just to support the devsHope yall make a survivalist 2....please call it something else, its a damn impossible name to search online.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												This is like an indie version of State of Decay, it's very well made and is probably one of the most underplayed indie games on steam.    It has all the elements of a good game, good story, good game play, lots of action, though choices, etc.   You basically have to start your own community and scavange other abandoned towns for supplies.   A lot of people complain about finding insulin for one of your community members however at day 40 of the game when I completed it I still had 11 or some to spare, so there is definitely enough in the game.   The game will make you make tough choices to find insulin in it, which is why there is the need for it.   If you don't play it the right way and let the person die that needs it, you will not get the full experience of the game, so make sure you play it right.   You will interact with other communities, you'll have to make some difficult decisions with them.   A lot of decisions you make can have unintended consequences, so choose wisely.If only the people who made day z would hire this developer, they might actually be able to finish their game ;)

Posted: February 22, 2015
												Great game concept. Author managed to get together elements of RTS, RPG and survival games to create well balanced and very pleasant game experience. You build a base and run (very basic) agriculture, scavenge supplies, explore the world and fill quests, developing your character. And, of course, fight zombies. Or other survivors. There are several shortcomings in each of these areas - low budget really shows - but game gave me (and I believe it will give to any old school RPG positive player) tens of hours of entertainment. Definitely must buy for a price and I will be definitely on lookout for more games from this author (Survivalist 2?).

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												I will have to preface this review with this one line:  This is literally the first game in over 2 years I am excited to come home and play.  Survivalist is an RPG/RTS hybrid, with sandbox elements baked in.  You start off as Joe, a financial hedge fund manager who has no practical skills and a boatload of worthless money, who lives in a 3x3 meter concrete bunker.  As you start, the game takes you through its tutorial phase, and I found it to be a quite easy to understand.  It covers most, if not all you need to learn about the game.  In about 1-2 hours you will learn how to build your base, scavenge for loot, and shoot zombies in style. However, this game shows its detail even in the tutorial, as you can completely skip it, and the game will remember this and assume you know the game, giving you full control over all functions.  It will also remember that you didn't get a certain community member and have certain events unfold!  But this is only the beginning of the game.  From there, you can quest by yourself or with a posse, forgo exploration and build your base and community, or build relations with not only the friendly communities but also the various looter or highwaymen gangs.  I found it a nice touch to be able to recruit what you would expect to be basic "bad guys", and then find out they have personality, and some even have their own story lines!  The quests range from difficult and strategic, mysteries to solve, or easy and borish... but expect the unexpected.  Much like real life, don't take all you hear at face value.  And this is, in my opinion, one of the strongest suits of the game.  Not only do you have multiple approaches to quests, but you'll quickly find out that not all quests are good for you.  I will also note here that the story, or main quest line, is really, really good.  I honestly haven't been engaged in a games story for many years, and this short story for some reason has me coming back for more.  The base building is in the basic RTS style.  You can set your community members out to gather resources, then have some other community members build various structures, while others do your farming, guarding, and exploring.  There aren't too many structures to build, but there is enough variety to work with.  However, the main break away from RTS style games is that your gatherer can also be your builder, soldier, explorer, farmer, doctor, or guard.  However, for veteran RTS players, the controls in Command mode(The RTS mode) are not as extensive as other RTS games. Combat in this game is simplistic, yet I found it quite fun.  Depending on your firearms skill, you can aim at the torso, legs, or head.  Aiming is heavily based on the firearms skill, with no stars in the skill meaning you cannot hit the broad side of a highway sign, to 5 stars where you can head shot all day long and rarely miss a shot.  The enemies you fight are not the slow type of zombie, these are the "Warp 9 engage!" zombies that can run down a galloping horse on speed.  Seriously, Aim for the legs!  I found this to be a fun, arcade-y style of combat, with reaction time being paramount between being zombie chow or using its skull for a cup.  However, even if they do get ahold of you, don't fret: you can give 'em a swift kick to get them off you.  This will use up your fatigue meter, which is based off of fitness.  Again, no stars = you can kick them off a couple times to 5 stars where you can go all Neo in the matrix, tossing them off repeatedly.  However, there are stronger zombies out there that will require more, if not all your strength to throw off.  The graphics aren't anything to write home about, but I did find them more than passable. For the most part they didn't break me away from the game in any form.  That said... the walking animation is not the greatest, and the sidestep animation reminds me of MC Hammer.  You can't touch this!  The soundtrack has a couple of good tunes in it, but to sum up: "Its good, but not great"  The controls I found to be spot on, and I could always get my character to do what I wanted, when I wanted.  In summery, I love this game.  I imagine I will be playing this for at least another 50 hours, and I spent a whoppin' 5 bucks on it.  I've gotten more enjoyment out of this game than most AAA stuff out there.  And if you are on the fence, you can even download the demo and try it yourself for free.  PS:  This game was made by one guy.  ONE.  Cudos to you, Bob, and thank you for producing a quality FULL game for an amazing price!

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												First of all I want to say… this game was just not for me, and so to people who know my likes well and have similar tastes, I would not recommend it. However, I can appreciate that although it may not be for me, it is actually a fairly good game and people who don’t have the same miffs with it that I do might really enjoy it (and actually have).That said, let’s get on with the review.Joe Wheeler, a self-centered businessman, leaves the safety of his bunker in search for food just about a year after the zombie apocalypse. The game is actually pretty run-of-the-mill post apocalyptic survival game, you have to scavenge, avoid looters, kill/escape zombies, build your own place in the world and overall just survive.The graphics are pretty good, not 3D masterpieces but I rather like the look of them; the game runs perfectly on older computers and the sounds and music are pretty alright as well.The Good:The game has lots of potential, and for being a one-man job, it’s really an amazing accomplishment on the developer’s part. The world seems to be quite large, the quests, although rather typical, are alright; the quest givers do remember your actions and any misstep will have consequences. You can go to war with factions, recruit people to your side, etc. You can use diplomacy, buy, sell, trade… The characters do seem to have some form of distinct personalities, and they are flawed in them. I really loved the touch of one of them having diabetes, it brought realism to the story. That there is a limited supply of insulin you must find/trade for also made it more realistic. But it also has the downside of making you feel truly rushed… You can split your party and give everyone commands. You can build things and plant crops.It has a fatigue system so you can’t just run forever, and I rather like that they added a needed sleep schedule to the hunger/thirst part of surviving.People can actually leave your party/settlement/faction when they don’t like you anymore.You can save at any time during the game, something that always wins my heart.The Bad:The default controls are super uncomfortable to me. Having to click F1 for the inventory is a stretch, using the middle button (mouse wheel button) to skip text is super uncomfortable. Entering a building is done through clicking with the mouse, but so is talking, and the menu for talking pops up as soon as someone is next to you, so sometimes the characters would stand right next to me when I was trying to enter a building which ended up in me talking to them when I didn’t want to.Overall it was a pain to do half the things I had to do.The characters who didn’t have a high shooting skill couldn’t shoot straight worth a damn. I get it this was probably going for realism, even Joe outright admits that he’s a bad shot. But there’s a bad shot, and there’s I-can’t-hit-a-target-even-when-it’s-on-me. The zombies were just way too fast and the aiming did not work quite as well when you had to be moving around all the time to avoid them jumping you from far too far. I found 0 melee weapons on the time I played (I honestly don’t know if there’s any), which admittedly wasn’t much. It was disturbing. I’d expect you’d find a baseball bat to smash a zombie’s head with before you’d find a gun…Then again I suppose since it’s a year later most people would be carrying guns… all the same, a backup melee weapon would have been nice to find.The game’s inventory is handled by a weight system, which is alright. However, it feels like you can’t really accomplish anything because everything you find to carry weighs too much and you end up having to make some very tough choices. This could be fine if you like a hard challenge, I’d rather get a bit more time to enjoy the game while surviving… Resource hunting is mind numbingly boring. Just getting the things to start building a fence took forever. Even with a backpack, because of the weight issue, the character can only bring one or two pieces of wood at a time. While realistic, this was also terribly frustrating - It takes longer to bring a piece of wood back to the shelter than it takes my characters to start getting hungry and sleepy and thirsty.The need for food/sleep/water/insulin seems too pressing. Again, good if you’re playing say, hard mode, but it doesn’t let you (or at least, wasn’t letting me) enjoy the game. I wasn’t even done figuring out a quest, and already they were starving. (Ok, not starving-starving, but already quite hungry).The AI seemed clunky when you left your guys alone. I left one doing the supply runs for wood so I could start building up something, he was attacked and bitten because I wasn’t there to press space when he got jumped. Had to restart because I was unable to get the needed antigen and I was fairly sure I couldn’t lose my only builder so far. All in all, while I loved the general premise and style of Survivalist, I couldn’t bring myself to fully enjoy the game as I felt rushed to get through it, and annoyed with the controls; yet I can see lots of potential in it. I was pretty split on recommending this game or not. In the end I’m going with a tentative “no” because to me the cons are a bit more annoying than the pros. Still, I can admit it's not a bad game.So, if you like a challenge in your survival games, then I would definitely recommend Survivalist to you. For the price it can be a great game. If you were expecting something a little more relaxed, I wouldn’t recommend it.There is word that there might be a multiplayer mode added, and I’m looking forward to see if it makes it any easier on the players by teaming up.* Key provided by Developer

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												"Again a game with zombies.... When will this end?"Well yes this is a game about zombies and YES zombie games are very common, some of them suck, some of them are medicore, and some of them are Very good, like this one.You start as a survivalist who has been in hiding in his bunker for 1 year in a zombie outbreak.After 1 year you get out of your bunker and meet some people who help you start a community.You have to search for food and water at the beginning. later you build a well for all your water needs and then you start your own farm which is a MUST because food will get scarce very fast.You will come across other communities. Some will give you quest opportunity, others will give you a bullet to the face or they will take al your gold (The game currency).If a character not from your community likes you very much you can recruit then in your community, making your community bigger and even stronger.you can give community members objectives and tasks which they must do to keep up (searching for construction materials/Farm/Guard).Skills are VERY important in this game, A character with a low fitness level and high firearms level is a smart choice to keep on lookout on one of your guard towers.Last but not least, the zombies.There are 5 types of zombies and there infection. (if they bite you you have limited time to find the right cure)Green eye's: Most common of all the 5, if they bite you have a very long time before the infection kills you. low HPBlue eye's: second most common of the 5. If they bite you you have a moderate amount of time before the infection kills you. Mid HPRed eye's: Rare, Infection will kill within a minute. High HPWhite eye's: Very rare, Infection will kill in seconds. Very high HPGray eye's(?): This infection is spread as a rumour so many don't belive in its existence, But it exists. I won''t tell it for spoiler reasons and I'm not going to make a spoiler tag because you will just look at it out of curiousity. In short, This game is worth the 5 euro, damn it is even worth 20 euro, If you like survival games which include social systems and zombies, don't wait just buy.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												the animations are really good for a 5$ indie game. I don't think it will have too much replayability.. i'm only a few hours in and i'm just now starting to contruct my base. overall my first 2 hours were really exciting.. it's fast paced, you can bleed out if you get scratched don't have bandages. good amount of items; pistol, shotgun, assualt rifle i've found so far.. it's a neat game.. if you're into zombie games like state of decay, it's worth 5$. Medical supplies can be traded for at NPC towns for gold. You find random items off the zombies and looters you kill. It's not a waste of money in my honest opinion. Try the demo out if you have any fears.Pro's-Free form construction of base, you decide where you build your walls one block at a time. also other buildings like guard houses, out houses, and houses for your npcs.-Other NPC bases to trade with/ attack/ loot/ or ally.. you decide.-Awesome action, npc's fight on their own. cool 2nd fight screen that shows everything in 3d around you.. it's really neat.-Easy to cycle between NPC's-Your builder will gather materials needed to complete project from the town without your supervision. Someone said they needed consant micromanagement, which was a total lie/lazy on their part. there is a bit of micromanaging between the two.. but it's not crazy time consuming.-RPG elements, skills increase with usage and time-NPC towns-Random events like Looters attacking your base, and zombie hordes coming for you-Farming and ways to stay sustainable-Enemies respawn after time, areas you clear of zombies will become dangerous again.Con's- the map is a very decent size, don't get me wrong. But i wish it were bigger.. -probably something like 14-15 hours of gameplayI love the game just wish it had more random generation and a sandbox mode for infinite gameplay.*** there is a cheat mode to add npc's and respawn towns with looters and other enemies. This would add more gameplay.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												tl;dr Worth it. So you're a hedge fund manager and you decide to buy up a bunch of land in the desert and construct a bunker and stock it full of food and supplies. Then Zday kicks off and you're living easy. Well that got you through the first hump but your supplies have run out. Now it's time to venture out and resupply and hopefully reconnect with whatever remains of civilization.What you find, rather unfortunately, is an emotional train wreck of a woman with an insulin problem who badgers you constantly and sets off warning bells every time her blood sugar gets too high. Then some pointless quests that are all focused on getting said waste-of-space woman more insulin so that she can complain again later that she's out. I've thought about kicking her out of the group so many times...That aside, you meet some interesting people and convince them to join you. Together you make a small community, build up some walls, put up a tower or two, some crops, a well, a few houses.. before you know it, you've got the sparks of a community you can call yours. you set the guard rotations, make sure your crops are being tended to, and put together an A Team of badasses with some heavy packs to loot the hell out of the desert. Let the good times roll.At 10 hours in I have just barely gotten to that point, and there is so much more to do... This game rocks. The controls are a bit funky (on 360 controller and/or mouse/keyboard) but you get used to them. Some of the interaction menus come up at the complete wrong times and can cause you to die, so my suggestion is to save often to avoid that. The graphics are great for this game and help with emersion. The music ranges from good and very fitting to the horrible non-stop out of place techno music that tends to give me a headache. I usually just save the game then reload the save to force a new song to go on. Some people complain about the reputation grinding, but it's not that bad. So you have to talk to a few people, do some work for them (which also gets you gold), and gift them an item... isn't that how it works in the real world too? It's completely fine.All around great game and for only $4.99 it's an instant buy if it's already on your wish list. So far I've gotten $0.50 an hour of enjoyment in my 10 hours of play and can easily see another 20-30 hours... Worth it.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												           Survivalist is a great game. The thing I like about it most is the fact that you can control an entire community of people. The trailor didn't necessarily do a good job of showing community so I will talk about that and then tell you some Pros and Cons of the game(there are way more Pros).           In the community you have to provide for each and every need that all your survivors have. You need to provide them with water, food, ammo, sleep,insulin (for Alice a person with type 1 Diabetes) and protection. You can farm crops or scavenge nearby towns for food. For water you can make wells or scavenge. For ammo you have to scavenge gun shops. And for sleep you need to make sure you have enough buildings constructed or taken over that provide your members with sleep. Each member has a certain amount of respect and approval for you and if you fail to provide them with these necesseties they will lose approval and respect. There are two ways to recruit people to join you. You can help them and make them like you and they might join, or you can force them to join you by having fun with a bullet and rifle. You can tell your people to be guards, farmers, build things, follow you and help you, medics, scavengers you can even set up a team to explore. These are just the first parts of owning a community but I hope it helped.           Here are the Pros and Cons        ProsYou can control your characters directly or in a control modeYou can control each characterThere is a huge variety in skills and a really cool skill systemThe game slowly gets harder and harder as you progressThe game has a cool zombie system with different strains that are harderThe game periodically sends hordes or groups of zombies and looters to attack your baseI love the missions in the gameGood online gameplay except for one thing(see Cons)    ConsGraphics aren't the bestSometimes glitches will happen when forcing someone to join your communityIn multiplayer if you get in a big fight against zombies the game will sometimes lagoverall I believe survivalist is a very clever and cool game and I really hope this review helped.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												First Impressions:This is a top-down action light RPG set in a post-apocalyptic world (with zombies, looters, and other communities). To quickly sum up what you can do, you can switch characters, loot houses (you cannot view the insides), manage inventories, send survivors on automatic supply runs, eat/drink/sleep/medicate to prevent from dying, build a base, embark on missions, trade using gold as a currency, and more.  I'm admittedly not that far into it, but so far I'm having a pretty good time with it.  There's a lot here for $5, though the combat can be a little too overwhelming at times...that is, zombies can run and mission difficulty can spike to impossible levels.  Despite its faults, it's a game you can easily pump four hours into (probably more), making it worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												I didn't think I'd like this game but I looove it. 7/10Features include:*Building a community, pretty much werhever you want really, but the game recommends you stay in a huge, defendable canyon*Scavenging food, water, bandages and luxuries to help improve you rrelations with your fellow survivors*Ability to recruit tons of survivors in the game, though recruiting means you have to do a lot of work or give gifts to them first*You can command survivors to do things, like scavenge certain resources from a building, defending from towers or pillboxes, or farming, which lasts untill you tell them to stop*Fun, exciting, but difficult quests that give some much needed color to this barren apocalypse*No loading screens except for loading, launching and jumping into your last save takes less then half a minute* You can beat bandits or other camps and force survivors to join youI really love playing this game and would recommend this to anyone, so they can get obsessed like me, however, there are some things that I'm not crazy about and hope they fix or add in the future, I'd play it all the time if they did already.Features I don't really like:*The main character is pretty bland and uncustomizable,  you play as Joe Wheeler, a wealthy man who hid away for a year from the zombie apocalypse in his own private bunker but now has to leave to find more food and resources*The entire map is pretty much a gigantic desert, though the locations are very interesting, being able to find a nice bit of green or a lake to settle near would be nice*Zombies are very powerful for some reason and some, even thought they're just individual zombies, will soak up dozens of your survivor's bullets, even with headshots*Leveling up skills takes forever, and some ou'll need to go out and find books that give you a bonus to that so you can actually use that skill, and then level up while using the book,*There actually aren't that many items in the game. There's canned food, chips, corn, bottled water, wood and chicken wire and cement, which makes up 80% of the items you need to gather in the game*No way to carry more stuff without backpacks, with the second largest backpack in the game, and just a pistol, you'll only be able to carry about 2 planks of wood; the survivors will only walk when you tell them to go gather resources, and you'll eventually have to go further and further away from camp, which is dangerous and can take about a half hour in real time to get maybe a dozen planks*Most of the time survivors will just stand around not really doing anything but complain, it'd be nice if there were more jobs to give, like cook, repairman, lumberer, doctor, rancher or miner*No customization at all*No animals at all*Corn is the only thing you can farm, but there's never enough of it*Survivors can't last longer then a real life hour going out questing as they need rest and eat and drink*Your community can grow up to the dozens, but there's only one way to switch characters, by cycling through them one by one*You can swap characters, but if your main character, Joe dies, game over,*The main characters starts out pretty much useless and you'll even have to swap characters because people will naturally not like Joe's personality or because Joe doesn't know how to hammer a fence*Equipping your survivors with a gun, bullets and a bulletproof vest takes up most of their inventory, leaving no room for loot*Bulletproof vests are the only protection you can wear *Switching, between your building's inventories and the survivors in it can be confusing*No categories to make searching inventories easier, like "Food and Water" "Weapons and Ammo" "Construction Materials"*There will be times that you get stuck, you'll have the people; not the food, you'll have the weapons; not the survivors, or you'll feel  like you have everything you need but your useeless diabetic friend needs more insulin which is expensive as hell and currency is really hard to find*You can only build two types of fences and gates and towers, and one pillbox, one type of house, and outhouses*It's implied you should keep everything in your bunker but that makes it very difficult to find what you're looking for, the only real option would be storing things in different houses*You can't negotiate peace in some cases, and some achievements want you to recruit some peoeple, which will either die or end up hating you for finishing quests you need to do.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Great game, especially at this price point. Not one crash or bug encountered in 16 hours of game play.Combat is fast and fun. Controls are intuitive. Controlling each individual survivor as well as being able to command them in command mode for repetitive tasks (like go get the 60 boards from that hardware store, 2 at a time) is very nice. The base building aspect is great. Roaming zombies and looters makes having some guards in guard towers useful.You can recruit pretty much anyone with the right approach, including the enemy looters in camps that people in towns tell you to kill. Getting them all to join you seems to work just as well as killing them, at least in the missions I've done so far.Quick tip for newbies: Try fighting green zombies hand to hand. Not only does it save bullets, it builds your fitness skill - which lets you carry more (much more with a good backpack) and keep the tougher zombies off you better. Just make sure not to sprint your stamina away before a fight, hand to hand does basically no damage when fatigued and you can't kick the zombies off you either. Once your skill is higher you can even fight off the tougher zombies with hand to hand. Another plus to having high fitness is you can do the boxing thing with npcs, which builds respect for you in addition to giving you money. I think high fitness even helps with making the NPCs who try to shake you down back off if you stand up to them (big buff guy more intimidating I guess). With a high fitness I was able to walk into a looter camp and shake down one of them, then recruit him forcibly and everyone else just by asking since they are now impressed with the way I handled myself.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												OK 6 hours in and I feel like I'm slowly turning into a green zombie myself. I really REALLY love this game.For me graphics aren't very important. I always compare to the film industry - there are so many shallow, big budget, gorgeous looking, but TERRIBLE films coming out ever since we had the technology to make them.However I am old school and graphics are meaningless compared to story, gameplay and how much you get sucked into a game.Yes you can get the odd title with all of the above including graphics, but you can't get them for the tiny sum these guys are asking.This game is deep, with plenty of fun quests that keep you playing and playing. It has some great base building gameplay which can take place independently at the same time as you are out shooting up the world, thanks to having programmable community members to build, farm and collect materials.You can build up your community and its members as you like, finding people with the required skills or training them up and hopefully keeping them alive. You can test your strategic skills by assaulting enemy camps or defending bases that you have designed completely yourself. Everyone you meet will have their own opinion of you depending on how you interact with them and the people they care about, affecting trade prices and available missions. You can lay waste to other communities or slowly recruit them all away to your base, or leave them intact as valuable outposts for trade and supplies in the middle of the wasteland. You can be as good or totally evil as you like and reap the consequences or rewards!You always need to keep moving and exploring to find the resources required to keep your people alive and it just draws you in!On the downside I did find the controls slightly clumsy and difficult to use in places to begin with, but it was quickly overcome. I would like to be able to change the camera angle though, unless I haven't found this yet. Also to start with I wasn't paying attention properly when placing buildings, so my first watchtower was the wrong way around and open and exposed to everyone beyond the wall! (not sure if this is actually reflected with defense penalties) I would like a feature to be able to rotate the buildings after building them without deleting them (although not realistic).I haven't tried co-op but I am really a single game player so my review would be meaningless on this.All in all you can really get completely absorbed into this world and these guys prove you don't have to have a VR set + next gen visuals to do that!

content:
Posted: January 6
												This game, oh man, where do i start?It is awesome, great fun to play especially with a friend. I've had my fair share of playing it. I bought it for only 1 euro, and i am 100% satisfied with my purchase. Look how much time i have in game.. 7.1 hours atm of writing this, but i betcha im going to record even more hours.This game isn't the kind of game that is going to be fun forever, it's the kind of game that is amazing for the price it is at. I purchased this for me AND my friend, we both enjoyed playing together, figuring out how to make others join us, laughing at the glitches...TL;DRPros :- A lot of fun for the price- There are new mechanics in the game, that could use some polishing but they are still awesome- Unique kind of game, the way you control the people and all that.- Full settlement building, fallout 4 scaled down.- The game is pretty darn stable in the current state.- The story goes pretty deep, each character has its own personality- The game will always surprise you, whenever you think "Oh i've seen it all" you explore that little area you have never been to before, and it has a new zombie type and a new character. Whaaat?- There are these constant raids, and zombie hoardes that keep attacking your settlement, It is really annoying at the beginning, since you can really easily get ♥♥♥♥ed because you have no walls. But if you do have walls, and the enemy is on the other side. You can always shoot and kill them extremly easely. If they are raiders and you have wooden walls, they are goin to throw molotoves on your walls and burn them down, be careful to make a wire fence walla and then a wooden wall. It's the most effective.- Did i mention the settlements? In my opinion it's better than fallout's, since if you get someone you can actually play as them and order them around- Ran out of fun? There's a cheat mode if you finish the game!- This game is a mix between strategy and top down shooter. It's a lot of fun.Cons :- Not so many items- Not so many buildings- The map is always the same, not generated.- Could use some better settings, and the optimization is garbage, i jump from 60fps to 30fps randomly.- Limited cast, you don't have any kind of character creator..

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This game is top 10 best games I have played, esspecially with the cost/playability ratio.  What, 3 bucks?  Damn, there is no reason not to try this game out.  It is basic, but entertaing and has yet to crash even once (Paging Bethesta, et, all, this is how you put a game out, it WORKS!!).  Congrats and praise for the Developer.   If you like "zombies" and TEOTWAWKI, by all means, spend your bucks.  I enjoy this much more than Dead State, or any other appocolyptic game I have bought in recent time.EDITED TO ADD:  Still playng, as I get further along it gets harder as I am juggling supplies with one group, building with another two recruits, farming and taking my action team further and further away from home.Some of the compliants are true, it can feel tedious, but I think a lot of that is the lack of the lazy man's fast travel and the fact that you have to think and experimant to find ways to progress, as there is little in the way of a cheati.  This game gives you little, you have to work for it.  Still better than Dead State, with much much more replay value.Combat isn't that bad (who the hell plays games without a mouse or a controller?!?!), and with a little practice I'm rocking it.  As for zombies out of no where, yeah, so what?  Fkrs are sneaky that way.  Wait till you get the sniper rifle, then you start seeing them first.  Also, don't run everywhere as you explore, gives you less reaction time to the zombies that come out of no where, and makes you tired.  Finally, LEARN TO DODGE, when they first jump at you, step to the side and kick or shoot them as they go past.  You can also stop them in their tracks with a first strike kick when they come at you.

												Firstly I'm going to say that I think some of these negative views are a bit unfair and are clearly here to advertise Home Behind...which in comparison is incredibly repetitive and at least in Survivalist you actually get to use what you collect to build up a base...but I'll leave a review on that game...I really enjoyed playing this game, because it is a great mix of scavenging and strategy gaming, with a good storyline and random generator (you never know when you'll suddenly be hunted down by a hoard of Zombies that have sniffed you out!) and it's really fun to scavenge and survive with the supplies you manage to get.I had some issues with the map area in terms of discovery, when trying to get rid of the 'black cloud' around my base camp and I think it could be better if you could choose to put your base wherever you wanted. content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Survivalist have some of the most interesting gameplay I have encountered in years. Zombie survival horror at it's very best, and it is far cheaper than it ought to be and similar titles. I suggest people try the demo, and then decide. I for one find it to be the best money spent on a game the last year. Do not get scared by the somewhat archaic looking graphics.Bob have maneged to single-handedly create a game that surpass most industry titles in gameplay, story and even character building. And, I am already looking forward to the next playthrough, with some different choices. Works wonders as a sandbox game too. The game-mechanics are good and functional, the game practically bug free (for me).Others critics have mentioned micro-manegement as somewhat of a hazzle at endgame, but the last community I built was over a 100 people, and it did not take as much micro management as I feared. It depends on playstyle I suspect. Most of the time, my people did their things without supervision. That said, there is manegement required, it ain't abojut the shoot, hack and slash. That said for my only grievance, hopefully future improvements will see optimization of the community member list, so you can sort by skill to pick the right survivor for a job. It took a lot of memory and notes to find that former looter who supposedly were great at farming, but needed that watering can you just found.I recommend the game, and encourage people to support Bobs efforts, as he really got something quite unique here.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												This game isn't worth $5... it's worth at least $15. The game is very immersive presenting you with ethical dilemmas such as, stealing to keep yourself alive, saving the many by damning the few, hell - there's even a literal gay couple dilemma in here. You heard me right, this game has a morale dilemma regarding the treatment of homosexuals. Now that's pretty damn immersive. While not listed this game IS a sandbox game as you have the option of building anywhere which makes the game even more immersive as you'll probably spend many hours simply deciding the layout of your base.There are a ton of quests. Most of these quests, if not all, have diverging paths you can decide from similar to Fallout or Skyrim.Combat is okay but could be improved. The lock-on system specifically is very annoying because I feel it doesn't compliment the fast-paced tackle/grapple style zombies use. Against human AI the lock-on system is more than adequate and is actually fun but against hordes of zombies it can get annoying. Coop is fun. You and your friends share the community members which works great as one person can handle the construction or farming and another person can finish up quests and scavange. During the difficult quests you can bring a friend or have your followers back you up. (Peer 2 Peer style coop - someone hosts, others join. No servers req.)The developer(s) has been pretty transparent with this game often replying to community questions in the forums. I believe a sequel is due and I look forward to playing it. If you're looking for a cheap game that you can easily spend 30+ hours on this is the one.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Survivalist. Just your normal top-down zombie shooter, right? Well, you couldnt be more wrong. You may look at the trailer and think: It has everything i want and more, quests, building, storyline. But, just like any other survival game, you'll get everything in a couple nights then be bored with it after. No, this is'nt just a survival game. There are Three different endings, an amazingly interesting storyline about how the outbreak began and more, So many different items, a constant challege with looters and zombies, you can shape your own story, Build a huge a** base and recruit everyone if you please, and best of all: You can literally do whatever you want. Whatever! Go ahead, kill a whole village! You dont like Isham Seely? Kill em off! You love the Fat Neils but hate the McCoys? Burn em to the ground! Now you may be thinking:, if i can just kill a whole village like that, what fun would it be? Wheres the challege? Well young one, killing a whole village would be extremly difficult. Thats why the possiblites with this game never end! You just cant get bored! Now you may think, how am i going to afford this game? It has to be 60$ or more with all this juicy content! No. Its 6$. I was rubbing my eyes when i saw the price too. Now i could go on and on about how great this game is, with all its missions and possiblites, but ill make you buy the game and play it yourself right here. Get your credit card ready.In a way its Skyrim because of its freedom and possiblites. Its also GTA because of its many weapons and many different characters.Its dungeons and dragons because it has so. many. items. And, enemies.Its binding of isaac because of the challenge.its the Civilization series because of its huge map and exploration.Its Civilization again because of its awesome building system and having to manage your people.Its the sims because of the many skills you can level up in.And finally, i couldnt find many games that have this feature. But ill go with FarCry because its so story rich. And, has different endings. (At least in FarCry 3.)Although all these games are so different from eachother, if they had a child it would be Survivalist. Even though i havent mentioned everything in survivalist, i hope you'll buy it. Being the owner of 400+ games (Including steam family sharing), it is one of the best games i have every played. Great job to Creator of this masterpiece. Now, time for you and me to clock in some hours on this game.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												I paid about $2.99 for the game and I have about 9 hours on it.Although there are many zombie games that involve base-building and scavenging supplies out there, Survivalist still remains a unique and enjoyable game to play.One problem, as you can guess from my relatively short time spent in this game, is replayability.  For the $3 that I paid I wouldn't penalise the game too much, but sadly once you're done with the game then there isn't much of a purpose to come back to it.  Most missions can only be completed in pretty much the same way.  The towns and resources are all pre-set (as far as I can tell), not dynamically generated, so exploration isn't a draw.Because of the lack of replay value, the game's limited time for a playthrough is also puzzling.  One character in the game has a medical condition and is reliant on a constant supply of medication.  This forces the player to complete the game within a certain timeframe as the supply is limited.  While certainly such a mechanic introduces urgency, it also serves to shorten the game.  I would have preferred the option to build and explore, instead of being so rushed.But Survivalist does some things very well.  Exploration is actually interesting, with towns being varied enough to make cars and houses worthwhile to explore.  You find things where you would reasonably expect them, such as water from a water tower (duh).  There is also an automated retrival system, where you can use NPCs you recruit to haul supplies back for you.  This offers a nice solution to the tedious task of resource retrival that other zombie survival games fall short on.NPCs are probably another strong feature of Survivalist.  Whereas most other games of the genre simply feature the sole survivor versus other zombies, Survivalist gives you NPC helpers.  Some of them are decently fleshed out and created, while others have no significant backstory.  The presence of NPCs helping you out makes for a much more interesting game, because it allows for an actualy plot beyond "don't get eaten".  Getting a quick message from a NPC that they are being attacked will cause me to drop what I'm doing and sprint back to base, because I sort of actually care about what happens to them.Co-op play is another area that has been getting more attention from the Devs.  I tried one session, which was okay.  Dropped in and took over a character.  Started running off to find supplies for the base.  Played for maybe half an hour until the other person logged off.  It's still not a very deep system and because I couldn't figure out how to communicate with the other player (say to figure out which resources I ought to be collecting) it was rather strange.Overall, Survivalist seems like a great work-in-progress game that (very importantly) carries a price like a work-in-progress game.  Although the content could be expanded, the underlying concept is fun and solid.

												Decent Survivor management game.Storyline and Gameplay are quite well done.The pace of the infected and enemy looters keeps the adrenaline pumping.Insulin is one of the major problem of the game, just to keep the diabetic female alive,can't see her in a prolonged game.To keep the game going without losing her,  use unorthodox method mentioned in the discussions.Management of a large camp can get really messy, trying to control too many survivor's activity isn't fluid.Constantly have to leave them standing around, trying to group them together, losing controls.Lack of respawns of items once you cleared the areas,other than just the same items and pistol from looter gang spawns, slightly better randoms and ammos of infected visiting the camp.NPCs who accidentally wanders off their usual path, into the routes of the infected/looters spawns get murdered for no reason.Rely too much on save/reload of game too frequently, as you never know the following few minutes, you might lose one of your favorite characters.Achievements aren't in sync with Steam, requires log out of game achievement updates, else all achievements obtained in current play will accumulate with same timestamp.Game is considered not bad if one keeps to the story, plays a short game, keeping a smaller camp.Read the game guides for npc infos on who to recruit for efficiency.Playable.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												Cheap, fun enough to play, I recommend. You won't get superb gameplay, but while it is simple enough it's also fun for a few hours. Pretty well developed storyline too.Doesn't really look special, but it's polished enough and at 5 dollars you get a simple but effective combat system, a base to build and manage, multiple npcs/characters you can switch to get a strategic element going on. 1 person guards base, 2nd gets building materials, 3rd (you?) goes around finding and talking to other npcs, get more npcs to do more stuff. Good rpg, good enough as a zombie survival game, combat system could be better (hold right click to auto aim at zombies, then shoot them and repeat. Longer you aim more accurate your shots get, red circle is fully accurate, can also aim at chest/legs/head for hits/slow down/criticals), zombies are incredibly fast, but it works. Also, there's a fast-forward system (which is probably why zombies are fast), which helps a lot while traversing the map.It's a pretty nice game, I played 24 hours without forcing myself too much to enjoy it, and this was before multiplayer support came out. Can be kind of tedious, grabbing materials to build base, getting attacked, getting food to grow, so if you have a dislike of managing a base it's not really the game for you. Or you could just go and ditch your allies, so you don't have to defend your base anymore. Suppose that is an option, I just don't like ditching useful npcs.You can also order your npcs to just water plants/go guard duty/grab materials from house, and they'll do it. They'll defend themselves while moving on, so if you leave them a pistol and enough ammo it works fine.Worth getting if on sale or full price, not that expensive and it's fun.
