Posted: March 27, 2016
												Survivalist is one of those games that you play that you can't wait for a sequel. There are a lot of great things about the game and there are some things that could have been done much better. First the pros:The storyline and content of the game are impressive. With a variety of win conditions that allow players to decide what type of person Joe Wheeler wants to become in the post apocalyptic nightmare that is his new life. It also has a plethora of recruitable NPC's which have their own backstories and personalities. The combat system is straight forward and as you increase your abilities you get more ways to ensure that in a fight you're the last one standing. The fact that your characters can be infected makes fights with the horde all that more dangerous since one bite and you better start running for some anti-gen otherwise get ready to lose one of your companions and be in danger of losing even more when they finally turn.Of course with a large cast of characters you're going to need more than just a small bunker in order to keep them all together. This leads into the construction system which is similar to combat in that the higher your level the more things you can do. Sure you can craft yourself a wooden gate but, if you want a watchtower you got to have the skills before you can actually build it. The game gives you a small tutorial though you have to complete it in a certain time limit if you want one of the characters to stay alive. It introduces you to all of the basic skills in the game but, does allow for some trial an error (no complete hand holding but, enough of a hand to know what you're doing.)One of the more unique takes on it has to do with the female lead. Since she's a type 1 diabetic she'll need insulin for the entire game if you want to keep her alive throguh it. This  allows for insight on exactly how difficult a post-apocalyptic world would be on those with poor health conditions. It also gives a sense of urgency to you depending on if you want to keep her alive or not. As far as the graphics go it's not excellent but, when you take into account the game was developed by one person it's much higher quality then certain games done by teams.For the con's there are quite a few but, mostly things that just required more work rather then actual demerits.First the Ally AI is fairly shoddy even if those characters are profecient in weapons they don't usually use the tactical skills that they have acquired (IE: no head shots or knee capping) in command mode they will either run full speed until their fatigue bar is full or they will walk at a normal pace. Unlike a player who would mix running with letting the fatigue bar lower after a while.Both of these can be reworked by messing with the AI however the important one (for survival sake in roming) so that a character will be told to "run" until the fatigue gauge is  at a certain level before going back to a walking pace.For consturction there is a far too little selection in the amount  of things you can build. A few different style of shaes would be nice or being able to set up automated defenses.Next, Farming. The farming system is fairly convoluted. First it takes several days before what you plant actually grows. Also it doesn't tell you when there is food ready at your camp so the farmer ends up hording it. The fact that the plants tend to blend into the ground doesn't help much either. Raising your skills- Even though you can get a character that doesn't mean their stats are perfect. However raising the skill of a single character takes a long of time and the game doesn't really give directions on how skill gain experience (other than the obvious of "using them increases skills)  Finally the last major issue is in combat or rather "ranged combat" If you're in a fight with a set of ranged enemies it's most likely not going to end well. Even with a bulletproof vest all it will do is protect from some of the damage as you get turned into swiss cheese. Fights can be won or lost on a dime when it comes to facing human eponentsAll in all I highly recommend this game in spite of it's faults because the game is very fun and gives a realistic view of what would happen if the "zombies" infested the planet. The only big problems are less about the actual game and more about the gameplay itself an how it could have done something better.Final score 8/10

												This is a fantastic game all-around. As many others have pointed out; it's definitely worth the very low price.Pros:Project Zomboid-esque freedom with a touch of the sims thrown in. The game is a legitimate free, open sandbox. The backstory, characters, and world are all well thought out. Controls are very straight forward, and the learning curve isn't too brutal or too casual. The progression; story, character, and gameplay!Cons:Single player.. which may or may not be a big deal. The insulin thing.. I won't spoil anything; but it makes it feel a lot less sandbox-y. Lack of character customization. The only thing I wish I could change about the game is that characters, traits and scenarios be a bit more random so that each playthrough could be as amazing as the first.In conclusion:A lot of other zombie, survival, or zombie-survival titles will not mete the itch quite as thoroughly as this one, and for less than it costs to eat at Subway... Eat flesh!

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												The game itself is very polished, which is rare for an indie developer now days.  I definitely appreciated that and it's worth mentioning.  I didn't come across any bugs or glitches though it did leave some things to be desired.  The AI seemed to work well for this game.  The basic concepts of survival was also fun, as were the quests.  The graphics are simple but worked for this game rather well, same with the interface.  I kept my community fairly small which I did prefer, it can quickly become a micromanaging nightmare after 10-15 members.Though the combat system was simple, I didn't like the heightened speed during combat.  Dying was so common and random during fighting with other "humans" you really had to save a lot and reload if the outcome wasn't desired.  Fighting the infected was only annoying if running on fast-forward, since you'd easily get bitten in a second even with fast response.  Again emphasizing on saving frequently.  Also not sure about the replay value but I expect to give it a try.  It felt quite linear the first run through.  Victory conditions are kinda lame and winning was a bit of a let down as well.  There's quite a few quests, I think every person has a "job" for you to do that increases your relation with them and their community.Overall the good does outweigh the bad in this one.  Try the demo out if you're in doubt.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Okay, I bought this game when it was on sale.I expected some half-baked game worth a few hours of fun.I. Was. Wrong.Typically, I am the type of person who isn't interested in games with zombies, and I thought I would give this game a shot.Granted, I initially played the game up until Alice gets her first five insulin and I stopped playing the game for 5 months.Eventually, I did return. I was bored, scrolling through my Steam Library when I saw this game."What the hell" I thought "might as well give it a shot".I played it for 30 minutes, which turned into an hour, which turned into 6 hours.I loved it. The game was amazing, and when I finished my first play through (I chose Love over Power and Money), I was hungry for more. I am now starting my second play through, choosing Power, which is no easy task.So far, I have not run into any bad bugs or glitches. The physics do sometimes do weird things, for instance, if you shoot a zombie as it is jumping at you, the body can end up going several feet behind you. A similar instance is when you kick a zombie in front of you, it can end up flying in the direction you pushed it, several feet away. Regardless, it's not a "bad" thing, just funny.My point is: give this game a shot. I initially hated it, but I grew to enjoy it a lot.Also, I realize that my review says that I have only played 0.8 hours of the game, but I played it offline on a separate harddrive.9.5 out of 10.A little tip: if you're going to threaten looters to get them to join you, use a character other than Joe. That way, there is less of a chance of people leaving your group (people often leave if they hate Joe).

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Creds to the devs who managed to create this game and sell it for just 5-6 bucks.It's basicially a survival-game were you create your own society in a post-apocalyptic setting.You trade, wage war, explore, recruit members and have the opportunity to shakedown and rob your neighbours.Every member in your society have certain skills and "state-bars" such as;Hunger, thirst, sleep deprevation and other depending on individual dependencies like smoking-lung cancer and diabetes type 1-insulin.The graphics certainly could be better, but takes nothing at all away from the game experience in overall, it sort of has its charm.For 5-6 bucks this game is a gem and showing us devs that appreciate the consumers and listens to the "crowd".It's not perfect, but at this low price - nothing would.Having 20 hours gameplay and still has a lot to explore and do, this certainly was worth my money.Big ups to the devs, keep feeding the consumers and take with you the appreciation from us.Hope your mindset rubs off on other devs!9/10

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												This game so far (7 hours into it at the time of writing) is extremely satisfying. a survival rpg sandbox type feel.  Graphically it is acceptable, but like many indie games, its the concept that truely sells the game.I would like to see more added to the game (although I suspect there is plenty for now), by addition, I think a mod kit would do this game wonders for community content, stories, romances, new enemies, memes and puns, etc.  such a open and fun world to mess around in. For the price, its a steal.Pros: Just all around a fun mixed genre game balancing out building survival, rpg, and exploration. Simple easy interface and controls. People who enjoy games like project zomboid, Dead State, and other type survival rpgs will enjoy this. Good price, could be a bit higher with more contentCons: the graphics are not very interesting. rather bland cartoonish top down borderlands but without the charm. the chat menu can become a nuscence (would rather hit a key that open/closes chat verses autopop open and close based on proximity).  the music...the music is so out of place and terrible that I had to shut it off and just play mood music from youtube in the background..change that pronto would be my suggestion.There is more pros and cons, and may update this down the road once I get a bit further on and truely test the limitations.8.5/10

												I have looked far and wide for an actually realistic zombie game, and just recently did I find this gem. Other games base themselves around shoot-em-up combat, but this game incorporates violence, character interaction, food, water, and medicine alike. The graphics are kind of funny at first but they kind of grow on you. I recommend turning off the music entirely because the soundtrack must've been chosen by an eight year old tripping on LSD... it ranges from techno to gentle piano to some kind of vocals to high pitched beeps. Anyway this game is probably worth $20 or more for how good it is, it's a steal at $5. I highly recommend you choose it if you crave a realistic zombie game.

												Here is another game that just takes a great game that should be worth so much more.  For the price, this game is a must buy for the zombie suvivalist lovers. Not only is the story very well written, but the attention to detail in characters, traits, base building, and weapons is top notch.  And what makes this game even more worth it? content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												The game itself is very polished, which is rare for an indie developer now days.  I definitely appreciated that and it's worth mentioning.  I didn't come across any bugs or glitches though it did leave some things to be desired.  The AI seemed to work well for this game.  The basic concepts of survival was also fun, as were the quests.  The graphics are simple but worked for this game rather well, same with the interface.  I kept my community fairly small which I did prefer, it can quickly become a micromanaging nightmare after 10-15 members.Though the combat system was simple, I didn't like the heightened speed during combat.  Dying was so common and random during fighting with other "humans" you really had to save a lot and reload if the outcome wasn't desired.  Fighting the infected was only annoying if running on fast-forward, since you'd easily get bitten in a second even with fast response.  Again emphasizing on saving frequently.  Also not sure about the replay value but I expect to give it a try.  It felt quite linear the first run through.  Victory conditions are kinda lame and winning was a bit of a let down as well.  There's quite a few quests, I think every person has a "job" for you to do that increases your relation with them and their community.Overall the good does outweigh the bad in this one.  Try the demo out if you're in doubt.

												Similar in a way to x2: threat and mount and blade: the gameplay itself isn't that fun, but the simplicity of it, and the ability to build an empire (settlement in this case) makes the game highly addictive and amazing. A minus - how many empires can you build? These games lack strategy requirements, they lack agility requirements... Sanboxes as this one are excersises in imagination - fun, but repetitive, if you play them too often. Overally? Very good game. Totaly awesome for the price - would pay more!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												Survivalist is one of those games that you play that you can't wait for a sequel. There are a lot of great things about the game and there are some things that could have been done much better. First the pros:The storyline and content of the game are impressive. With a variety of win conditions that allow players to decide what type of person Joe Wheeler wants to become in the post apocalyptic nightmare that is his new life. It also has a plethora of recruitable NPC's which have their own backstories and personalities. The combat system is straight forward and as you increase your abilities you get more ways to ensure that in a fight you're the last one standing. The fact that your characters can be infected makes fights with the horde all that more dangerous since one bite and you better start running for some anti-gen otherwise get ready to lose one of your companions and be in danger of losing even more when they finally turn.Of course with a large cast of characters you're going to need more than just a small bunker in order to keep them all together. This leads into the construction system which is similar to combat in that the higher your level the more things you can do. Sure you can craft yourself a wooden gate but, if you want a watchtower you got to have the skills before you can actually build it. The game gives you a small tutorial though you have to complete it in a certain time limit if you want one of the characters to stay alive. It introduces you to all of the basic skills in the game but, does allow for some trial an error (no complete hand holding but, enough of a hand to know what you're doing.)One of the more unique takes on it has to do with the female lead. Since she's a type 1 diabetic she'll need insulin for the entire game if you want to keep her alive throguh it. This  allows for insight on exactly how difficult a post-apocalyptic world would be on those with poor health conditions. It also gives a sense of urgency to you depending on if you want to keep her alive or not. As far as the graphics go it's not excellent but, when you take into account the game was developed by one person it's much higher quality then certain games done by teams.For the con's there are quite a few but, mostly things that just required more work rather then actual demerits.First the Ally AI is fairly shoddy even if those characters are profecient in weapons they don't usually use the tactical skills that they have acquired (IE: no head shots or knee capping) in command mode they will either run full speed until their fatigue bar is full or they will walk at a normal pace. Unlike a player who would mix running with letting the fatigue bar lower after a while.Both of these can be reworked by messing with the AI however the important one (for survival sake in roming) so that a character will be told to "run" until the fatigue gauge is  at a certain level before going back to a walking pace.For consturction there is a far too little selection in the amount  of things you can build. A few different style of shaes would be nice or being able to set up automated defenses.Next, Farming. The farming system is fairly convoluted. First it takes several days before what you plant actually grows. Also it doesn't tell you when there is food ready at your camp so the farmer ends up hording it. The fact that the plants tend to blend into the ground doesn't help much either. Raising your skills- Even though you can get a character that doesn't mean their stats are perfect. However raising the skill of a single character takes a long of time and the game doesn't really give directions on how skill gain experience (other than the obvious of "using them increases skills)  Finally the last major issue is in combat or rather "ranged combat" If you're in a fight with a set of ranged enemies it's most likely not going to end well. Even with a bulletproof vest all it will do is protect from some of the damage as you get turned into swiss cheese. Fights can be won or lost on a dime when it comes to facing human eponentsAll in all I highly recommend this game in spite of it's faults because the game is very fun and gives a realistic view of what would happen if the "zombies" infested the planet. The only big problems are less about the actual game and more about the gameplay itself an how it could have done something better.Final score 8/10

Posted: March 27, 2015
												This game is a really fanastic one. It puts you in charge of an entire community that you have to build up. You get missions to carry out for gold, you get raiders who track you from across the map, and you ge different zombies that pop up randomly. I'm just going to list the main ups and downsUps-almost everyone can join your community-Food and water are easy enough to get but hard enough to still be a task-controls are simple and easy to learn-each character has their own story-each character has their opinions of other charactersDowns-when you don't have many people, tasks can get very long and tedious-The weight of items that each character can carry is only about 20-25 pounds-It is difficult to get a new person into your community-special items, such as backpacks, are very hard to find. I reccomend this game to anyone, but it isnt and action packed shooter or hardcore survival like "The Forest"

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												I'm absolutely addicted to this game, which I must add was purchased for under $5!!!  Although not too customizable (except for backpacks and weapons), and you'll damn the day you promised to chase this desert non-stop for whatever limited quantities of insulin there are left for an individual who essentially is just a stranger to you, it all seems to fall into the right places.  The insulin chase adds the element of urgency to the whole thing, otherwise you'd turn this experience into a city builder sim.  Scraping by, and fighting tooth and nail to survive, is your humble beginning.  Leading a tactical squad later on in the game is when it really pays off.  Really wish there were armor options aside from bullet proof vests, both for armor and cosmetics.  Oh well, no big deal really.  Great game, great price, great entertainment.

												This game is a really fanastic one. It puts you in charge of an entire community that you have to build up. You get missions to carry out for gold, you get raiders who track you from across the map, and you ge different zombies that pop up randomly. I'm just going to list the main ups and downsUps-almost everyone can join your community-Food and water are easy enough to get but hard enough to still be a task-controls are simple and easy to learn-each character has their own story-each character has their opinions of other charactersDowns-when you don't have many people, tasks can get very long and tedious-The weight of items that each character can carry is only about 20-25 pounds-It is difficult to get a new person into your community-special items, such as backpacks, are very hard to find. I reccomend this game to anyone, but it isnt and action packed shooter or hardcore survival like "The Forest"

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												This game is a lot of fun! It is kind of hard though because one group member is diabetic and needs a steady supply of insulin. Encumberance is an issue as you try to decide what you should loot and what you should leave behind which makes for some really difficult choices. Graphics: Old School, and simplistic, but they work just fine.Controls: Pretty good.Story: Decent.Sound FX: Decent.Music: Fabulous!Group Dynamics: Yes you can play another group member or you can send them to gather or build and assign them jobs.Open World: Yes, it is pretty big as far as I can tell, and you can do missions (mostly) in whatever order you prefer.Crafting: Yes, a little bit, there are things to build and things you can make.Zombies: Many seem to be fast, but I have encountered some that are slow.Baddies: Some raiders out there need taken care of old school style.Missions: Some are easy and some are hard. I am far from done.Gameplay: Fun! There is plenty here to keep you very busy. Building a base will take a lot of time. There really is a lot to explore and a lot of character interaction. NPC's have wants and needs. Exploration is enjoyable wiping out cloud of war.Advice: Get a backpack!Money: It's worthless.Ammo: Priceless!Insulin: Rediculously overpriced =(10/10 Will give the photograph to Old Man Toby again!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												ALMOST the ultimate zombie survival game!You follow a hedge fund manager who took the ultimate hedge: he stocked an emergency bunker in the Mojave desert in case of a disaster.  And it paid off.Manage multiple settlement members, press-gang thugs and looters to join you, keep your populace happy, keep everyone fed (or they'll get stupid), watch out for the undead trailing you back to your base, and looters tracking you back as well.Social and reputation mechanics are simple but functional, though they could be a bit more transparent.  Transportation and water are your most important concerns.  Different grades of infected and infection serve different levels of danger.The ONLY reason this game isn't THE BEST is that it lacks a bit of 'full feature' fleshing out.I'd like to see:more structures (kitchen/canteen, concrete barricades, mine, tents, barbed wire, stakes, irrigation...)more types of food (particularly involving nutrition and craft cooking!  We can't eat corn forever!)more crafting (melee weapons, fletching, clothes, duct-tape engineering) more advancement (wooden fences have an upgrade, mines add rails, people start asking for hot showers and solar heaters)vehicles and gasoline scavenginghouse dangers (narrow sightlines and darkness make buildings more dangerous than being outside in the daytime!)Annexing buildings (I know 'the dead can smell where we used to live', but surely they can smell where twenty people are living NOW, too!  Don't just let us, MAKE us claim certain kinds of pre-disaster buildings for benefits and requirements!)And of course...  character creation.  I'd really like to start a sandbox style of game with all of this going on that doesn't force me to play the jackass hedge fund manager.  Don't get me wrong, I LOVE that the hedgefund manager is a jackass, not a negotiator, but the interplay between social skills, potential, and current skill level makes for some intriguing characters, not to mention the little things like lung cancer, or being a diabetic (which the game ALREADY HAS!).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Gotta say i put more time into the game, and it just isn't that fun. It's ok at first, but it needs some vast improvement before i play again.I enjoyed the soundtrack at first, but when you roam around for long periods of time the same 3 loops over and over again start to get dull (and quite annoying).The gunplay feels ok at best, but it mostly comes down to how much ammo you have, not how much damage a gun does or how skilled you are. The base building is a joke, as you have to have someone that's skilled as a mechanic to even carry THE SUPPLIES for building a base back home! Why would i need to how how to use barbed wife and planks to carry the bloody things around?!?While i enjoy the lack of voice acting, the dialogue is mediocre and the characters feel as bland and lifeless as the undead they are fighting off. The least you could do is give each character a personalty, as they aren't randomly generated and you will run into the same people time and time again.I also feel that the game forces you along certain paths, and here's an example of what i mean: I was doing a quest for someone at one of the forts, she wanted to go see some guy she left at a police station. I liked the guy better then i liked her, as he seemed pretty polite and would make a better addition to my group. So i shot her and recruited the guy. I saved in a different slot and started my way back to my base. Half way home my people at my bunker kept getting killed. So i set the main guy on the course for home and switched back to the carpenter at my base. Turns out, the people from the fort of the woman i shot sent a death squad to my base. It may sound logical at first, but i was halfway across the damn map when i shot her! HOW ARE THEY GOING TO KNOW?!? It wasn't even a little while after either, it was right when it happened! Unless you're armed to the teeth, you are going to get annihilated. So i you even stray a little of the path the game thinks you should go on, you get severely punished.Over all, it's a mediocre survival game with decent potential, but poor execution. I'll give this game another shot down the line to see if it is improved, but in it's current state, i strongly reccomend spending your money elsewhere.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Similar in a way to x2: threat and mount and blade: the gameplay itself isn't that fun, but the simplicity of it, and the ability to build an empire (settlement in this case) makes the game highly addictive and amazing. Worth trying, esp. if you like Mount and Blade or X: series, but played them long time ago so you will not get bored easly. On a side note - it has some advanced character options compared to other games (you can make standard quests for people, give them gifts) + the quests are generally better than Mount and Blade. A minus - how many empires can you build? These games lack strategy requirements, they lack agility requirements... Sanboxes as this one are excersises in imagination - fun, but repetitive, if you play them too often. Overally? Very good game. Totaly awesome for the price - would pay more!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I like this game, but there are some things about it that I would recommend changing:1) Moving supplies is way too tedious.  Why can't you use a cart or a wheelbarrow?2) Your bunker is probably not the best place to set up a base.  Why not reclaim a town or area that already has some fortifications built up?3) I agree with some of the other posters that the top down view seems way too zoomed in, its hard to see zombies coming and you have very little time to line up your shot before they jump on you.4) Trying to keep the diabetic woman supplied with insulin is a constant distraction.  I would prefer if there were some in game option that would allow you to ditch her, or find a permanent supply of insulin that was closer to your starting location.  (The game makes it seem like she is important to the plot)5) I like the idea of ammo and supplies generally being plentiful, because it is far more realistic.  I also like that your carrying capacity is about 20 pounds, or 50 with a backpack, because that also makes sense.  Also, kudos for no ammo in garbage cans.6) I understand your game engine's limitations and why you don't have functioning cars, but maybe come up with a reason why they don't work?  Like there is a severe gas shortage or economic crisis?  Also, why does Wheeler have a radio in his bunker, or a TV?  Why did he wait so long before he went out and got more food?

												Wow. there is not much to dislike about this game. Also, there is a lot to like about it. What is to like? Well, Let's start with how real this game feels. When I hop into the world created by these developers I feel immersed. I enjoy how difficult it can be and how you can feel the danger. Another  thing I like is all of the added mechanics. The ability to customize the layout of your base and choose the best defense scheme is a great addition. Although this isnt the most immersive game, such is State of Decay in my opinion, it is a well designed and thought through game which i truly enjoy. Now the downers in the game. The POV I very much so dislike top view cameras. I cannot stand them and that really puts me off this game. However the other mechanics really make up for this.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Wow, cheap as chips 9especially in steam sale) but despite it's budget graphics and game mechanics this is a solid survival game. The story flows to let you collect people for your community and learn the basics, but once you get past that it's hella difficult. I completed the start quests and whislt having to split the party suddenly looters tracked our footprints back to our bunker that wasn't defended. now half my crew have severe injuries that require healing. The best part is also the most annoying part, one of the companions I've collected is diabetic and yes, you require a supply of insulin, which you need gold to buy, so now I have to do jobs around a nearby settlement. Deceivingly complex, not sure if I get to make the choice of just executing the sick yet...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Great game, amazing deal for the price you're paying.Pros-Decent story (I personally did the love ending and I found the story to be great but that may differ on which win condition you choose-Fairly challenging game-Lots of surprises which makes the gameplay a lot more exciting, you must expect the unexpected-Controls are a bit awkward at first, but as you get used to them it becomes fairly smooth and convienient-It contains elements of townbuilding, which would be a plus or minus depending on what you like (I personally liked this aspect of the game)Cons-Moving from one side to another is quite the pain since you have to have your character run the whole thing and running consumes stamina and low stamina makes you vulnerable to zombie bites so it can take quite a bit of time just getting to one place to another-The lack of a group auto function for example, have 4 survivalists farming and managing them as a group so you dont have to go to each one and tell them to farm-Sniper rifle is pretty broken, it lets you deal with a huge number of looters without much risk (I guess this isnt really a big issue since sniper rifle ammo is quite rare, but even so)Overall, I would highly recommend this game. Lots of fun, defintely one of the more enjoyable indie games Ive played.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I have looked far and wide for an actually realistic zombie game, and just recently did I find this gem. Other games base themselves around shoot-em-up combat, but this game incorporates violence, character interaction, food, water, and medicine alike. The graphics are kind of funny at first but they kind of grow on you. I recommend turning off the music entirely because the soundtrack must've been chosen by an eight year old tripping on LSD... it ranges from techno to gentle piano to some kind of vocals to high pitched beeps. Anyway this game is probably worth $20 or more for how good it is, it's a steal at $5. I highly recommend you choose it if you crave a realistic zombie game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Talk about gems just popping up on the radar.This is the kind of great idea you'd expect to see as a half-baked early access title never to truly see the light of day. But out of nowhere appears before me a complete game of the post-apocalypse where your decisions affect the game in meaningful ways.This is just not done often enough.The gameplay may take a little getting used to for some as it is not conventional. Personally, I was an expert after a whole of five minutes of minimal handholding.I feel like I'm playing a game I can really sink my fangs into. An excellent buy at five; I didn't bother waiting for a sale after playing the demo (I tend to find that is another good sign, when a developer goes out of their way to publish a demo along with their title... I find even AAA titles don't even go so far). If you don't believe me, give that demo a shot. If this is your kind of game, I'm sure you will be sold in minutes, as I was.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												ALMOST the ultimate zombie survival game!You follow a hedge fund manager who took the ultimate hedge: he stocked an emergency bunker in the Mojave desert in case of a disaster.  And it paid off.Manage multiple settlement members, press-gang thugs and looters to join you, keep your populace happy, keep everyone fed (or they'll get stupid), watch out for the undead trailing you back to your base, and looters tracking you back as well.Social and reputation mechanics are simple but functional, though they could be a bit more transparent.  Transportation and water are your most important concerns.  Different grades of infected and infection serve different levels of danger.The ONLY reason this game isn't THE BEST is that it lacks a bit of 'full feature' fleshing out.I'd like to see:more structures (kitchen/canteen, concrete barricades, mine, tents, barbed wire, stakes, irrigation...)more types of food (particularly involving nutrition and craft cooking!  We can't eat corn forever!)more crafting (melee weapons, fletching, clothes, duct-tape engineering) more advancement (wooden fences have an upgrade, mines add rails, people start asking for hot showers and solar heaters)vehicles and gasoline scavenginghouse dangers (narrow sightlines and darkness make buildings more dangerous than being outside in the daytime!)Annexing buildings (I know 'the dead can smell where we used to live', but surely they can smell where twenty people are living NOW, too!  Don't just let us, MAKE us claim certain kinds of pre-disaster buildings for benefits and requirements!)And of course...  character creation.  I'd really like to start a sandbox style of game with all of this going on that doesn't force me to play the jackass hedge fund manager.  Don't get me wrong, I LOVE that the hedgefund manager is a jackass, not a negotiator, but the interplay between social skills, potential, and current skill level makes for some intriguing characters, not to mention the little things like lung cancer, or being a diabetic (which the game ALREADY HAS!).

												PROS: - Lots of suprise and a good story line.- Map is vast and there is a decent amount of content to explore.- Characters are interesting for the most part.- Gameplay overall is entertaining and addicting.CONS:- Not the greatest soundtrack.- Combat, although fun, is quite wonky (Targeting is horrible).- Characters can barely see 10ft in front of them.- Bugs with the soundtrack and gameplay take away from the experience.Personal Notes:- The audio clip that plays when you are out of stamina cannot be controlled by the other audio sliders and cuts off suddenly.- Targetting system should be put in place (Press this button to switch enemy you're locked onto).- The game has a lot of promise for good multiplayer gameplay as well as sandbox gameplay (with random maps).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Sometimes you have less than $5 in your Steam wallet and decide to roll the dice on an Indie title and it pays off. Survivalist is one of those diamonds in the rough that delivers a satisfying zombie survival/RPG suitable for the nostalgic gamer like myself-meaning you've got to have hard-core gaming chops and a strong stomach for retro visuals. The environment responsive face-cam window on the UI was an interesting choice but ill-concieved considering that the portrait models look like♥♥♥♥♥♥overall the art of this game-is pretty terrible quality on the close-up components-especially on the conversation exchanges and the title screen despite having "good enough" graphics to accomplish its gameplay goals plus nice aesthetics and environmental set design in the overworld. It harkens back to the old Fallout games in a lot of ways visually and in terms of deep narrative but with a less advanced and comprehensive dialogue system and using a real-time combat system rather than the turn-based tactical systems of those pre-Bethesda games. There is a more acute survival component and a community building element that while somewhat clunky provides something similar to a low-fidelity Fallout 4.My first 2 hours with the game almost caused me to return it because even with the tutorial it is hard to get in to at first-in fact-I would say the tutorial is to blame. The main character of the tutorial should have been the girl with diabeetus-then "you" as the player would have to value her as a non-expendable character and be thereby compelled to follow the linear sequence to the point of obtaining and maintaining your supply of insulin. The plot around this is somewhat nonsensicle with Joe as the main character having to begrudingly accept her and it is unclear in the beginning how linear the game intends to be on account of the forced dialogue and character scripting around these events. You can deviate from the linear story but you will suffer for it in multiple ways...but it also has its advantages if you survive. The key is understanding that the reload option push from a failed mission is a courtesy and not a command-you can continue on after failing an objective-such as not responding to a certain SOS signal before thirst and diabeetus takes it toll but you will not able to access a few features until you recruit some additional members nor will you have the necessary construction training or tutorials available for base building with Isham.  The combat will be too fast paced for many I fear and harassment from random roaving mobs (especially if they are looters) from even the first two towns will discourage a lot of folks from going forward with the game given the time differential between building a fence versus time it takes to burn by molotov cocktail.You've got to be willing to give this ugly duckling a lot time to develop into the totally awesome but slightly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ plaid & polka-dotted flamingo that it will become...and you've got to love grinding and have lots of time and patience for  running around the desert, reading conversation text including asking everybody their name and "what's up?' then beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of them for money as the most legit job available. I have been considering using this game for some videos on my channel but it would need to be heavily edited because the time it takes to do things on this game are ungodly. That said, it is pretty brilliant in a lot of ways and the only reason I am so hard on it is because I see the massive potential for the game (or the announced sequel-since Bob indicated that after MP was added the game was done and he was shifting focus to that) Here's hoping that you will be able to roll a character with military/police, athelte, bartering/social-skills, farmer/construction worker, stealth/thief skills, and medicial archetypes and customizable secondary skills to help organize community roles better than just having stackable skill books that anyone can use which although easy is kind of lame. Having no stealth, melee weapons, vehicles, nor a robust skill and item crafting system seems criminally negligent and the addition of these critcal elements along with more adequate dialogue options and less detracting visuals to a sequel would go along ways to making it truly outrageous...I'd buy that for a dollar ;)The fact that this joint was only $3 both explains and excuses many criticisms but the dude who made this is my hero and I wish I could spend some hours with him to explain to him basic stuff like how much lumber weighs and that while backpacks may increase the number of small items a person can carry comfortably it does not in fact make them able to carry more weight than they could before donning the backpack...but hey ya know it's a game and I like it anyway.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I had my doubts about the game when I first saw its graphics, but this is EXACTLY what I want out of a Zombie game. There are different factions, plenty of people to talk to and see what they're doing. The AI is actually pretty good, whether its in combat or just general moving about (except when they're stupid enough to walk to the nearest source of wooden planks/chicken wire/cement, which just happens to cut through an unexplored, unsafe white strain zone with 100 bullets and a pistol...) it all seems pretty fluid. Once you've visited a town, hordes will pick up your scent and will track you back to your bunker every now and again, meaning once you've built up a little nest egg, you wont be sitting there bored out of your mind. Also, there are looters! They track you back to your bunker and try to destroy you as well. Think your wooden walls will keep them out? They come packed with molotovs as I unfortunately found out. Once you've upgraded to Chicken Wire you'll be pretty safe... Until someone comes along with an RPG. Fortunately theres only 20 of them in the game, but thats still plenty enough to kick your♥♥♥♥♥

												Probably one of the best zombie apocalypse games I have played. The main thing i like about the game is the ability to set your people to different jobs, I don't know if there is a limit to the amount of people you can have at once but for now I have 4. 1 man is my lookout who basically stays in the watch tower for most of the day, another one is my scavenger who looks through abandoned houses and cars for anything useful like food or ammo, then my last 2 work in a team, one goes to collect wood to build my fences to keep out zombies or looters and the man with him is just their as fire power incase he runs in to trouble on his own.I was searching the area with 3 of my people and came across an older couple who set up life on top of a small hill, the old man started to disrespect me so I killed him then asked his wife to join my community, she said no so I thought to myself I have no reason to keep her alive and killed her too. 10/10 You should definitely buy this game if you're in to strategy as the choices you make affect your story.

content:
Posted: January 19
												this game, it's a great game. You can set it to 60 fps mode from within its settings, but if you've played it on 30 fps mode the majority of the time it's gonna be a little weird and even feel sped up when you make the switch.What can I say here? I really enjoyed using two characters to build things and help manage the community by building a couple wells. scavenging for building materials, food, water and even in some cases meds gives the game a more realistic zombie apocalypse experience than some others will give you. Ammunition is very important and not having enough can be the difference in being overwhelmed or not. You have to build your own community, it'll be difficult, but you'll get there... or you know, you can try to mostly solo it and see where that goes as well. The game has so much freedom in it. An example being you can build random stuff nearly anywhere, so long as your character has the materials and building skill for it. Recommended if you enjoy a survival, community building, community managing simulator game. It's also a bit of an open world third person shooter.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1
												Absolute gem of a game. It'd be a crime not to buy it for 2.50 on sale. It may seem like a basic zombie indie game, but trust me when I say that it runs much deeper than one can imagine.It's one of the better zombie survival games out there. It's shocking how much content (game mechanics, map size, dialogue and quests) there is in such a small game. There is a huge map to explore, with areas separated by different strains of zombies that act as difficulty barriers. Plenty of loot and communities spread around, with some hidden areas as well. You can capture enemies alive and make them work for you in your community, or kill pretty much anyone except the main character, without the game ending. Almost everyone (except zombies and some generic looters) are named which is sweet. Characters have personality profiles and preferences. Zombie strains infect you via bite at different speeds (how many days / hours it takes to turn) and people who die to a zombie bite can turn into a named zombie, which will be marked on the map and stay there forever when killed (serves as a cool reminder of who you lose). Can build your own place anywhere on the map, plant crops, make wells, etc. but has a lack of crafting (can't craft weapons, ammo, clothes).Combat is basic, aim at something and wait for the reticle to turn red before shooting for an accurate shot. Depends on your firearm skill and the weapon you're using, as well as if you're in a watchtower or not (elevation seems to confer bonus for you and debuff for enemy, vice versa). It's a bit fast paced, especially when fighting humans, but the mechanics are very solid. Get shot in the arm and have a debuff to your firearms, for example. Bleeding requires bandages or cloth. View distance and weapon range depends on weapons that you're using (sniper rifle having one of the longest ranges and view distance, as far as I know).Dialogue is fairly simple for all characters, but have a lot of contextual meaning. You can always ask someone what's up (their interests), what's their opinion of you, for work, offer them gifts, offer to trade supplies, hold them up (as in rob them) or kill them. What's cool is that if someone is thirsty, hungry or is injured, they can ask nearby people for help (free or paid). Who you talk to (and how you talk to them) can affect your characters relationship with that person as well as their friends and enemies. Who you use to talk to the character also matters, so just because one person in your community knows the name of another and are good friends, doesn't mean that everyone in your community has the same relation with that person.There are numerous quests scattered throughout, and aside from the main quests, some of the smaller ones involve fisticuffs or taking out a group of looters. There are some big main quests which have interesting stories.Most buildings can be destroyed and you can occupy (and fortify) existing buildings rather than building your own (so technically you don't really need construction skills). Buildings have a weight limit to the amount of things it can carry which is cool.Inventory management is a nightmare without a backpack and fitness skills.Skill books in the game can be stacked for multiple skill level bonuses. Skills themselves are varied, in that whilst level 5 is the maximum, some characters can only attain 1~4 levels in a certain skill. So job dedication does sort of matter.Eat, sleep, drink. Some people also have special conditions, like diabetes requiring insulin, or lung cancer, etc.You can recruit a crap ton of people for your community. It's almost silly running around with a 10 man raid group.Best of all, press G to fast forward the game. Saves so much time running to and from or when you are just idling cause people are asleep or carrying loot back home.

content:
Posted: April 11
												I would recommend this game to everyone if you're into open world survival games. This game gives me TWD feels, I feel like the main character is Rick Grimes. Don't hesitate to add this to your library, this game is good for killing time or even playing with your friends.Pros:-Different roads(not literally a road, okay?), every decision you made have consequences.-Open world! You're free to do everything you want! Everyone wants that.-Many quest to do from NPC's and some of them requires something before getting or taking those quest(Like trust etc.)-You're able to conquer other communities, or even make your own base at your own will.-I like how you can control your camera view. That's +1 for me in every game.-I also love how you can train your character or people on some certain skills.Cons:-I really hate to say but I feel like the crafting system is less. I wish there's more in the crafting system.-The saving system makes the game so easy, if you did something wrong you can just re-your previous saved.Overall, It's a fun game to play. It's worth spending your money on this one.
